questiontext.text:
This is a Numerical question.

Solve $$x^2 + 3x - 28 = 0$$

Enter either of the possible answers.

generalfeedback.text:
The quadratic equation is $$\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}$$

a = 1, b = 3 and c = -28.

$$x = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{3^2 - 4\times 1\times(-28)}}{2\times a}$$

$$x = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{9 + 112}}{2}$$

$$x = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{121}}{2}$$

$$x = \frac{-3 \pm 11}{2}$$

$$x = \frac{-14}{2}$$ or $$\frac{8}{2}$$

p>and the solutions are x = -7 and x = 4.

p>We can prove these are correct by substituting the values into the original equation.

p>$$(-7)^2 + 3\times(-7) - 28 = 49 - 21 - 28 = 0$$

p>$$4^2 + 3\times4 - 28 = 16 + 12 -28 = 0$$

hint.text:
You may need to be reminded of the quadratic formula
$$\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}$$

You will need to substitute for a, b and c in the quadratic formula
$$\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}$$

a is the coefficient for $$x^2$$, b is coefficient for $$x$$ and c is the constant.

questiontext.text: The equation \(- 3 x^{2} - 3 x - 3=0\) has at least a solution.
The solutions for the equation \(- {a} x^{2} - {b} x - {c}=0\) are:
\(\)The equation \(- 3 x^{2} - 3 x - 1=0\) has at least a solution.
\(\)The equation \(- 3 x^{2} - 3 x + 1=0\) has no real solution
\(\)The equation \(- 3 x^{2} - 3 x + 2=0\) has no real solution.

Compute the eigenvalues of the following matrix

$$\begin{equation}\begin{pmatrix}x&y\\y&z\end{pmatrix},\end{equation}$$

where \(x\) = {=(1+{rand1}*(5-1))}, \(y\) = {=(1+{rand2}*(5-1))} and \(z\) = {=(1+{rand3}*(5-1))}.
